author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

author: By Neil Sheehan Special to The New York Times

headline: Gravel Says Group Urges Killing of Dovish Senators

headline: Buckley Urges April 1 Ban on Draftees in Vietnam

author: By Clayton Knowles

headline: FREEDOM IN PERIL LIBRARIAN WARNS
lead_paragraph: DETROIT, June 30 — The president of the American Library Association called today for “more vigorous responses” to what he characterized as a growing threat to intellectual freedom stemming from “hysterical charges and counter charges.”
author: By Henry Raymont Special to The New York Times

author: By Morris Kaplan

author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Observer: A Blue‐Ribbon Investigation

author: By Russell Baker

headline: 5 Presidents Agreed: Bruce Is a ‘Giant’

Bruce, was America's senior Ambassador. headline: F.B.I. INVESTIGATES RECORDED MESSAGE

headline: NIXON APPOINTS BRUCE AS LEADER AT PEACE TALKS

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times

headline: ALLIES IN SWEEP NEAR PNOMPENH

headline: In The Nation: One‐Two Punch in the Senate
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 1—Seldom if ever has a President suffered the sort of one‐two punch with which the Senate smote Mr. Nixon on Tuesday —passing the Cooper‐Church amendment on Cambodia and overriding the President's veto of the health aid bill, 76 to 19.

headline: Looting by Saigon Units Stirs Cambodian Hatred

author: By Sydney H. Schanberg Special to The New York Times

headline: Conviction Overturned In Desecration of Flag

headline: Laos Reports the Recapture Of Mountain From Enemy

headline: WAR FILM DROPPED BY BERLIN FESTIVAL
lead_paragraph: BERLIN, July 3 (AP)—The jury at the 20th annual West Berlin Film Festival has dropped from competition West German movie about an alleged American atrocity in Vietnam, authoritative sources reported today.

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: On the Fourth of July we celebrate the fact that we are a self‐governing people rather than servants paying tribute to some foreign power. It is a special day of thanksgiving for our hard ‐won and hard ‐to ‐hold freedom of thought, speech, press and assembly. We raise our flag as a testimonial symbol of our right to individuality as long as that individuality is not clearly inconsistent with the general welfare or the security of the nation.

headline: Boat Hits Mine
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 3 (AP)—Forty‐six South Vietnamese civilians were killed today when a passenger river boat struck a floating mine south of the demilitarized zone. Local officials said it was the highest toll from such an incident in memory.

headline: CAPITAL PREPARES FOR JULY 4 EVENT

headline: Gen. Abrams Undergoes Gall Bladder Surgery
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 3 (UPI)—Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, United States military commander in Vietnam, underwent successful surgery in Japan today for the removal of his gall bladder. The surgery had been delayed until now so he could direct the recent United States operation in Cambodia.

headline: In Cambodia, Gloom Returns After the U.S. Pullout

headline: ROGERS AND THAI CLASH IN MANILA

author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Terms the Naming Of Bruce a ‘Correction’

headline: Muskie's Timetable: Out of Indochina In 18 Months
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON. WHEN President Nixon took office, most Americans hoped that his Administration would find the key to the Vietnam problem. We wanted to end our preoccupation with the war and get on with unfinished national business. Unfortunately, the Administration has not found the key, and the war in Indochina continues to dominate our lives. Having invaded Cambodia in an attempt to score dramatic military gains, the Administration finds itself ever more tightly bound to the war and its consequences. We cannot pry ourselves loose by force of arms, and we cannot dictate the peace.
author: By Edmund S. Muskie

headline: Economic Lag Threatens G. O. P. Chances in Senate

headline: 14 Senate Doves Ask That F.C.C. Force the Networks to Provide TV Time
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 8—A bipartisan group of 14 Senators filed a complaint today against the three television networks charging that they were being denied an opportunity to pre sent their views against the Administration's policy in Viet nam.
author: By John W. Finney  Special to The New York Times

headline: Bruce and Paris Talks
author: By Henry Giniger  Special to The New York Times

headline: Marine's Trial to Begin
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UP1) —United States District judge John Lewis Smith Jr. said to day he lacked jurisdiction to slop the court‐martial of a Ma rine Corps private accused of killing 16 Vietnamese civilian last February. Pfc. Samuel G. Green. of Clevland, is sched died to go on trial July 20 in Vietnam.

headline: Buckley Pledges Support That Nixon Can ‘Count On’ in Senate
lead_paragraph: The Conservative party's candidate for United States Senator, James L. Buckley said yesterday that he would back both President Nixon's efforts to win peace in the Middle East and Southeast Asia and his foreign policy in general.
author: By Will Lissner

headline: ASIANS URGING U.S. NOT TO WITHDRAW
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, July 8—South Viet nam and Cambodia, and South Korea, Thailand and Philippines as well, have told Secretary of State William P. Rogers that the United States must not re duce its military, political and economic commitments in the Pacific region in any serious way.
author: By Tad Szulc  Special to The New York Times

headline: Pacification Struggle: Saigon and Foe Compete for Young Talent
lead_paragraph: SOMEWHERE IN SOUTH VIETNAM, July 5—An Amer ican general and his civilian and military intelligence spe cialists filed into the austere living room of a young Amer ican who is the chief adviser to the local South Vietnamese province chief.
author: By William Beecher  Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The President has revived the domino theory in his TV inter view by citing as evidence the views of Lee Kuan Yew and Tunku Abdul Rahman. In the past both of those leaders stated very grave reservations about the U.S. intervention in Vietnam and publicly urged far stronger emphasis on peaceful negotiation than we have given.

headline: HOUSE THWARTS EFFORT TO ADOPT WAR FUNDS CURB
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 9—With the Nixon Administration's sup port, the House leadership thwarted an attempt by anti war Representatives today to force an immediate vote on the Senate's Cooper‐Church amend ment restricting future military operations in Cambodia.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: LAIRD SAYS SOVIET BUILDS UP ICBM'S AT INTENSIVE RATE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 9—Sec retary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that the So viet Union was continuing to deploy intercontinental ballis tic missiles at a rate that would dramatically increase its offen sive nuclear‐striking force.
author: By Neil Sheehan Special to The New York Times

headline: Plans for Korea Cutback Approved, Laird Asserts
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 9—Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird, citing budgetary pres sures and the Nixon doctrine, said today that plans had been approved for the removal of some American troops from South Korea.

headline: Sihanouk Says North Korea Offered Him Troops
lead_paragraph: PEKING, July 9 — Prince Norodom Sihanouk said today that he felt tempted to call in North Korean troops to help liberate his country. He said premier Kim II Sung urged him recently to accept volunteers.
author: By Norman Webster© 1970 The Globe and Mail, Toronto

headline: U.S. Urges Prison Reform by Saigon
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 9—The United States is trying to persuade the South Vietnamese Government to do away with, the so‐called “tiger cages” at its island prison on Con Son, 140 miles southeast of Saigon.
author: By Robert M. Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Thant, Opening Parley, Urges Youth of World to Help Reduce Tension
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 9—The World Youth Assembly opened today with a plea from Secretary Gen eral Thant for idealistic youth to lead the world away from tension—an appeal that was quickly lost under a blanket of wide‐ranging political at tacks coming mainly from leftist delegations. Youths—some in sport shirts with skimpy beards and a smaller number of women variously attired in African cottons, pants suits or miniskirts moved into the seats of the great domed General Assem bly hall usually reserved for high‐ranking ministers and diplomats. For once, the reg ular delegates, who turned out for the opening of the nine‐day assembly, were seat ed in the rear as silent. On lookers. The youths’ speeches were unpolished, the events were confused and often con tradictory, and the whole af fair for the moment led no where. But for sheer spirit and verve the youths macle the United Nations ’ occasion ally well‐mannered debate seem faintly like a prayer meeting. A small but seem ingly well‐disciplined group of delegates was notably active. Every suggestion to expel groups from South Vietnam, South Korea and Nationalist China was applauded enthusi astically and there were many such motions, mostly from the Eastern Europeans.
author: By Kathleen Teltsch Special to The New York Times

headline: American General Missing in Vietnam With Six in Copter
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 9 — The United States Army disclosed today that Maj. Gen. George W. Casey, who di rected the withdrawal of the last American ground troops from Cambodia on June 29, has been missing since Tuesday when he took off in his heli copter. An intensive search is under way, an Army spokesman said.

headline: Rogers Says Red China Is Key to Indochina Peace
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, July 9—Secretary of State William P. Rogers described Communist China today as the key to the future of Indochina and said that peace settlement could be worked out “very quickly” if Peking showed enough interest.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. COURT WIDENS RIGHTS OF HOLDERS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 9—Cor porate shareholders have broad rights to participate in corpo rate decisions that have social impact and any denial of those rights has to he based on clear ly stated reasons, the United States Court of Appeals here has held.
author: By Eileen Shanahan Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. WAR DEATHS Al 3½‐YEAR LOW
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 9—The United States Command reported today that 61 Ameri cans were killed in action in the Indochina war last week, the lowest toll in more than three and a half years.

headline: Black to Oppose Humphrey
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL, July 9 (AP)—Earl D. Craig, Jr. a black instruc tor at the University of Minne sota and an outspoken critic of the Vietnam war, filed yes terday to oppose former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey for the United States Senate nomination.

headline: SONGMY FIGURE BIDS U.S. JUDGE BAR TRIAL
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex., July 10 (UPI) —S. Sgt. David Mitchell of the Army filed suit today in Federal Court to block the Army from trying him on 31 counts of assault to commit murder in connection with the alleged Songmy massacre and to have charges against him transferred to a civilian court.

headline: Secretary Rogers'
lead_paragraph: Any hope the Administration may have entertained for pursuing a strong proxy fight against the Communists in Cambodia must have been dashed by the responses Secretary of State Rogers has met during his extended Asian tour.

headline: THIEU URGES A HALT TO VETERANS'
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 10 (Reuters) — After an extraordinary conference of South Vietnam's top military and political leaders, President Nguyen Van Thieu called on dissident war veterans today to halt their protests and give the Government time to solve their problems.

headline: MANSFIELD SEES A 2D NIXON TERM
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 10 —Senator Mike Mansfield, the Democratic leader of the Senate, predicted today that President Nixon would win re‐election in 1972, as things now appear, despite foreign and domestic problems.
author: By Warren Weaver Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: China's Jails Still Hold 4 Americans
lead_paragraph: When the Most Rev. James Edward Walsh, unshaven and dressed in faded khaki trousers and an old checked shirt, crossed into Hong Kong yesterday, he left behind four Americans still detained in Communist China's prisons.

headline: AMERICAN IN HANOI SAYS HE'S DESERTER
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, July 10 (Agence France‐Presse) — A young man introduced as United States marine said at news conference here today that he had left his unit in South Vietnam in February, 1969, and had been with the Vietcong until this month.

headline: Senate Votes Again for Tonkin Repeal
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 10—The Senate placed on record today, for the second time in less than a month, its wish to repeal the 1964 Gulf of Tonkin Resolution, which was cited by President Lyndon B. Johnson as Congressional authorization for the war in Vietnam.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: 87 Senators Score P.O.W. Treatment In Letter to Hanoi
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) —Eighty‐seven Senators put aside differences on the Indochina war today to demand that Hanoi end “inhumane treatment” of American war prisoners.

headline: Is the House a Rubber Stamp?
lead_paragraph: Efforts to reassert the authority of Congress in vital decisions concerning war and peace have in the last few days received a double blow in the House of Representatives.

headline: Rogers in Britain for Talks On Mideast, Asia and NATO
lead_paragraph: LONDON, July 10 (Reuters) —Secretary of State William P. Rogers arrived here tonight for a two‐day official visit and said his talks with Britain's new Conservative, leaders would center on the Middle East, Indochina and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

headline: Saigon Is Investigating ‘Tiger Cage’ Cells at a Prison
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 10 (Reuters) — The South Vietnamese Government promised today to abolish the ‘'tiger cage” punishment cells in Con Son Prison if an investigation confirmed the criticism of two United States Representatives and press reports of the mistreatment of prisoners.

headline: GENERAL'S COPTER FOUND IN VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 11 — The United States command announced yesterday that searchers had found the wreckage of the helicopter of Maj. Gen. George W. Casey, the commander of the First Cavalry Division (Airmobile), but withheld most details pending the completion of recovery operations.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: GOLDBERG ACCUSED OF SKIPPING ISSUES
lead_paragraph: PATCHOGUE, L. I., July 10—Paul Adams, the Conservative party candidate for Governor, tonight accused Arthur J. Goldberg, the Democratic candidate, of blocking discussion of important state isues by centering his campaign on the war in Vietnam and the sending of planes to Israel.

headline: Youth Assembly Clashes Over Move to Oust Delegates
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 10—Led by Lars Thalen, a strong‐willed Swede wielding a swift gavel, the World Youth Assembly stopped a leftist group's drive today to exclude young participants from Nationalist China, South Korea and South Vietnam.
author: By Kathleen Teltsch Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Green Berets, in War Since '62, Said to Be Pulling Out This Year
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 11—The Green Berets, troops of the United States Special Forces, who were the first American fighting men in this country early in the nineteen sixties, will be phased out of South Vietnam by the end of this year, according to reliable military sources.

headline: In The Nation: Democracy in Action
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 10— President Nixon had good rea son to be “elated,” as was re ported when he heard that the House had supported him in pre liminary votes on the Cooper Church amendment to restrict future military operations in Cambodia. But there may have been some side effects that will not be so welcome, to him or to those Democratic leaders who apparently worked closely with him to achieve the vic tory.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Recordings
lead_paragraph: THE question of contro versy in art is a can of worms. While con troversy rages, the in trinsic values of the artwork in the spotlight are difficult to discuss because the con troversy tends to rise out of non‐artistic issues which are usually social, political or economic. Was Strauss's “Sa lome” so controversial at its premiere in New York be cause the dissonant score pushed music theory another step past tonality, or was it because the Dance of Seven Veils threatened Victorian morality? Was Pete Seeger prevented from singing all of his anti‐Vietnam war song. “The Big Muddy,” on the now‐defunct CBS‐TV Smoth ers Brothers Comedy Hour a few years ago because the ditty shattered folksong tradi tions or because “the big fool” who said to “push on” in the lyrics was a carica ture of Lyndon Johnson? pushed music theory another step past tonality, or was it because the Dance of Seven Veils threatened Victorian morality? Was Pete Seeger prevented from singing all of his anti‐Vietnam war song. “The Big Muddy,” on the now‐defunct CBS‐TV Smoth ers Brothers Comedy Hour a few years ago because the ditty shattered folksong tradi tions or because “the big fool” who said to “push on” in the lyrics was a carica ture of Lyndon Johnson?
author: By Howard Klein

headline: U.S. Reports Finding 7 Bodies In General's Copter in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 11 (UPI)—The United States command said today that seven bodies had been recovered from the wreckage of a helicopter that had carried Maj. Gen. George William Casey, the commander of the First Cavalry Division (Air mobile).

headline: Saigon Police Halt Protest Including U.S. Marchers
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 11 — Policemen using tear gas broke up a march today by South Vietnamese students and a visiting American delegation here to assess the peace move ment.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Officer Tells Court‐Martial He Ordered G.I. to Kill Man
lead_paragraph: LONGBINH, South Vietnam, July 11 (AP)—First Lieut. James Brian Duffy told an Army court martial here today that he had ordered Specialist 4 John R. La Nasa to execute a Vietnam ese prisoner suspected of be ing a Vietcong.

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: British Rule in Ireland

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM—“We are not as impressionable as we were back in 1967,” an Israeli official said over the heavy, North‐European unch that officials here offer their guests and that is as little suited to Jerusalem's dazzling climate as the black kaftans of the Hassidim.
author: —Takashi Oka

headline: Saigon Repatriates 86 Prisoners
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 11 (AP)—South Vietnamese au thorities sent 62 war prisoners and 24 fishermen back to North Vietnam today. The 86 men were taken in a South Vietnamese Navy vessel to a point six miles off North Viet nam and delivered to two mo torized junks.

headline: Intellectuals As an ‘Ethnic Group’
lead_paragraph: AMERICA'S intellectual elite, nor mally secure from criticism, has been taking some lumps lately—and not just from Spiro Agnew. Writing in The Nation, John McDermott has accused lower‐level members of the elite of thinking of themselves as missionaries bringing culture to the heathens, and Michael Lerner, in The American Scholar, anticipated Agnew with the sugges tion that the intellectual leaders may be snobs. Culture is indeed mission aried at some of the working‐class institutions (state colleges are what I have in mind) at which exiled members of this elite are forced to teach to earn their daily bread, and snobbery is as present among this elite as among other groups of human beings.
author: By Andrew M. Greeley

headline: Agnew Affirms ‘Partisan’ Role But Bars Presidential Ambition
lead_paragraph: Vice President Agnew has acknowledged that his political role in the Administration some times forces him into a “hard line” stance, but he has dis avowed Presidential ambitions for himself.

headline: OFFICERS DOUBT A SPEEDY PULLOUT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 11 — Knowledgable military sources here believe that the Nixon Administration's Vietnam strat egy may require it to keep a large American military con tingent in South Vietnam. roughly 150,000 to 200,000 men, as late as 1972.
author: By Neil Sheehan Special to The New York Times

headline: Democrats Zero in On Their Target: Nixon
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the un seen voter shakes money out of his cookie jar and stuffs it into an envelope to send to the Democratic party in Washing ton, a voice observes: “You don't have to wait until 1972 to vote against Richard Nixon.”
author: —Warren Weaver Jr

headline: STUDENTS ACTIVE ON FALL POLITICS
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N. J., July 11— While many of their fellows are soaking up the summer sun, students at dozens of colleges across the country are already hard at work preparing for po litical campaigns next fall.
author: By Steven V. Roberts Special to The New York Times

headline: WAR STAND SPLITS EPISCOPAL CHURCH
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD, July 11—The Episcopal Diocese of Connecti cut has called on its member parishes to refuse to partici pate in a fund drive to support, student antiwar strikes.

headline: Bonn Votes a Surcharge On Taxes to Curb Inflation
lead_paragraph: BONN, July 11 — The West German Parliament approved today a Government bill to combat inflation through a number of tax measures, includ ing a 10 per cent refundable surcharge on personal and cor poration taxes.

headline: Allies May Use Guerrillas To Hit Foe's Supply Lines!
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 11 — Allied strategists are planning to use the enemy's own tactic—guerrilla warfare— to try to frustrate North Viet nam's efforts to develop an al ternate supply route for its forces in Cambodia and south ern Darts of South Vietnam.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: RED TROOPS ENTER CAMBODIA RESORT
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 11—In a resumption of major military action, the Vietnamese Communists were reported this morning to have entered the strategically situated mountain top resort of Kirirom, about 60 miles southwest of Pnompenh.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Education
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO—City high schools have been in turmoil during the past academic year, and educators have tended to attribute the students unrest al most exclusively to external causes—the Vietnam War, ra cial conflict, permissive child rearing.
author: —Fred M. Hechinger

headline: 384 OF THE ENEMY REPORTED KILLED IN KHESANH FIGHT
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday. July 13 — A United States helicopter‐borne assault and a B‐52 raid that followed were reported today to have killed at least 384 North Viet namese soldiers and to have wounded many more. American officials termed the action the sharpest setback in months for enemy forces in South Vietnam.

headline: Rogers Expects No Moves By Hanoi for Peace Now
lead_paragraph: LONDON, July 12 — Secre tary of State William P. Rogers has concluded during his two‐ week journey in Asia and to Britain that the Communists have no immediate interest in negotiating a peace settlement in Vietnam.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Steinbeck's Son Denies Demonstrating in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 12 (AP)—One of three United States newsmen arrested yes terday during a student dem onstration here said today that they had been seized because they were taking pictures of police activities.

headline: Migrant Camps Assailed
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 12 (Reu ters)—Senator Walter F. Mon dale charged tonight that camps tor migratory laborers in Texas and Florida were similar to con crete cages in which political prisoners were held on South Vietnam's Conson Prison Is land. In a speech prepared for Senate delivery tomorrow the Minnesota Democrat said a study “finds the lives of hun dreds of thousands of our fel ow citizens manipulated and managed in such a way as to ?? them to subhuman sta tus. I am shorked and outraged ??eyond belief.”

headline: Mothers to Protest War
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, July 12 (AP)—A group of women who call them selves Concerned American Mothers plans to go to Wash ington Wednesday to press for an end to the war. A march they plan in front of the White House Friday is scheduled to coincide with a reception for Prince Charles and Princess Anne of Britain.

headline: LAYMEN CRITICIZE PARISH SCHOOL AID
lead_paragraph: LA JOLLA. Calif., July 12— The National Association of Laymen, an organization of 12,000 Roman Catholics, has decided that one of its prime activities this year will be op position to state aid to paro chial schools.

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Senators Back National Health Plan

headline: Political Steps to End War Are Urged by Montgomery
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) —Cyrus S. Eaton, the Cleveland industrialist and longtime advo cate of closer ties with the So viet Union, said today that the famed British soldier, Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery believed “a political end to the war in Vietnam is the only pos sible way to end that war.”

headline: U.S. Vietnam Force Cut to 411,500
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 13 — The United States com mand reported today that the number of American troops in, South Vietnam had dropped to 411,500, the lowest in more than three years.

headline: Suit Accuses F.B.I. of Checking Peace Group's Bank Records
lead_paragraph: The Fifth Avenue Peace Parade Committee has filed a suit in Federal Court charging that the Federal Bureau of In vestigation used confidential bank records to obtain informa tion about opponents of the war in Indochina.
author: By Arnold H. Lubasch

headline: Hamlet, Its Men With Vietcong, Resists Pacification
lead_paragraph: BINHSON HAMLET, Souti Vietnam, July 10—The trouble in Binhson hamlet is all the missing men. They left to join the Vietcong.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: A NIXON JOB OFFER IS HELD REBUFFED
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 13— The White House choice for di rector of Volunteers in Service to America is reported to have rejected the appointment be cause of sharp disagreement with President Nixon's Indo china and domestic policies.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘Tact‐Finding’ in Saigon
lead_paragraph: Under belated pressure from the United States Embassy, the South Vietnamese Government has prom ised provisionally to abolish the inhuman “tiger cage” punishment cells uncovered by two unorthodox Con gressional investigators, Representatives Augustus F. Hawkins of California, and William R. Anderson of Tennessee. The two Congressmen departed from an otherwise routine “fact‐finding” junket to visit the prison and expose the “tiger cages” which had been described to them by a former prisoner.

headline: House Panel Urges U.S. to Investigate ‘Tiger Cage’ Cells
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 13‐ A House watchdog committee today demanded a prompt and thorough Federal investi gation of conditions at South Vietnam's Con Son Prison, where “tiger‐cage imprison ment and savage mistreat ment of human beings” was charged last week by two Representatives who visited the scene.
author: By Felix Belair Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Ceylon‐North Korea Link
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 13— The Government of Ceylon has extended full diplomatic recog nition to North Korea. Since it came to power in May, the coalition regime of Mrs. Siri mavo Bandaranaike, the Prime Minister, has recognized East Germany and has pledged to establish full relations with North Vietnam and the provi sional revolutionary govern ment of the Vietcong.

headline: Westmoreland Visits G.I.'s at Fire Base in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: FIRE SUPPORT BASE VEG HEL, South Vietnam, July 13— Gen. William C. Westmoreland, back in Vietnam for the first time since he left two years ago to be Army Chief of Staff, dropped in today at this post near Hue and voiced optimism about the war.
author: By Sydney K Schanberg Special to The New York Times

headline: INCREASE IS URGED IN MONEY SUPPLY
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 13— Two former Government econ omists urged today that the Federal Reserve Board permit a somewhat greater increase in the money supply than was the case in the first half of this year, partly in order to help restore “liquidity” in the economy.

headline: Nixon Picks Ambassador To Serve in Pnompenh
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 13— President Nixon has decided to step up diplomatic relations with the new Cambodian Gov ernment of Premier Lon Nol by naming Emory C. Swank, a senior diplomat, as the first United States Ambassador to Cambodia since 1965.
author: By Hedrick Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Aides See Evidence Hanoi Troops Shift South
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 13—American intelligence of ficials have turned up evidence of a movement toward South Vietnam by some North Viet namese regiments well north of the demilitarized zone.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Montgomery Asserts Eaton Broke Confidence on Nixon
lead_paragraph: LONDON, July 13 (UPI)— Field Marshal Viscount Mont gomery said today that the United States industrialist, Cy rus S. Eaton, had broken a con fidence in making public a let ter saying President Nixon was “totally unfit to be Commander in Chief of the United States armed forces.”

headline: NEW GROUP TO BACK A BILL TO END WAR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) —A citizens committee was set up today to organize grass roots support for a bill to re quire United States withdrawal from Indochina.

headline: Market Place:
lead_paragraph: It may well be that the best thing the economy and the stock market have going for them is the prohibitively costly burden of waging war in Indochina.
author: By Robert Metz

headline: U.N. YOUTH PARLEY CURBS TWO GROUPS
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 13—Youthful participants from South Vietnam and Na tionalist China were denied the right to speak at the World Youth Assembly today, prompt ing 30 delegates from 19 coun tries to walk out in protest.
author: By Kathleen Teltsch Special to The New York Times

headline: CAMBODIAN FORCE BATTLES ENEMY ON KEY HIGHWAY
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 14—A battle raged tonight about 55 miles from Pnompenh on the highway linking the cap ital with the port of Kompong Som, the former Sihanoukville.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: 500 FROM CON SON FLOWN TO SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 14—More than 500 prisoners have been flown on American] military planes from the Con Son Prison to Saigon and are awaiting release, a South Viet namese Government spokesman said here today.

headline: SOVIET AIDE ENDS NEW DELHI TALKS
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI, July 14 — Nikolai P. ??ryubin, a Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, left this morning after having con ferred with Indian officials about the prospects of a new Indochina conference.

headline: Vote‐Rigging Dismays a Vietnam Province
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 14—A case of flagrant vote‐rigging has discouraged officials and reinforced the cynicism of villagers in a small province along South. Viet nam's coastline.
author: By Takashi Oka Special to The New York Times

headline: Policy Dispute Denied as the Reason for Rejection of VISTA Post
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 14 — Apparently yielding to White House pressure, Richard Blumenthal said today that his decision to decline appointment as director of Volunteers in Service to America—VISTA had not been based on dis agreement with Administration policies dealing with the poor.

headline: Red Cross Findings Cited By THOMAS J. HAMILTON
lead_paragraph: GENEVA, July 14 — Red Cross inspectors have found in two visits that conditions at the South Vietnamese prison at Con Son were “not too bad” and that a vast majority of the inmates were held as corn mon criminals, reliable sources disclosed today.

headline: House Panel Urges That Federal Courts Be Given Jurisdiction Over Military Crimes of Ex‐G.I.'s
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 14— A House panel that investigated the alleged killing of Viet namese civilians at Songmy recommended today that the jurisdiction of the Federal courts be expanded to deal with military offenders who have be come civilians.

headline: Marxist Saws Die Hard
lead_paragraph: The old Marxist charge that capitalist economies depend on war to provide prosperity and full employment dies hard. Not only orthodox Communists but radicals of the New Left take it as axiomatic that what used to be known as “mer chants of death” and is now called “the military‐industrial complex” controls the nation's basic foreign and domestic poli cies. The “com plex” does this, according to the Marxist doctrine, not by conspiring against the eco nomic interests of business and labor but by actually serving the interests of those who seek higher profits and wages through the expansion of the capitalist system.
author: By Leonard S. Silk

headline: Laird Keeps Close Eye on South Vietnam's Economy
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 14 — The newest and most anxious student of South Vietnam's economic problems here is Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird, whose interest is aroused by fears of a precipi tate decline in the morale and effectiveness of Saigon's army.
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: 180 File for Saigon Senate
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 14—One hundred eighty candidates will vie for 30 of the 60 seats in South Viet nam's Senate, in elections Aug. 30. The central election committee announced the names of the candidates and the tickets on which they are running today, after the filing deadline of midnight last night.

headline: 3 NAVAL OFFICERS GET COURT SETBACK
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) —Three junior naval officers have met a setback in efforts to block their early discharge that the Navy acknowledged stemmed in part from their antiwar activities.

headline: House Panel Says the Army Hampered Investigation Into Songmy Incident
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 15 — Members of a House panel that investigated the alleged mass killing of Vietnamese civilians at Songmy stepped up their criticism of the Army today, contending that it had ham pered their investigation.

headline: BRITAIN AND FRANCE BACK JARRING ROLE
lead_paragraph: PARIS, July 15 — The For eign Ministers of Britain and France agreed here today that the United Nations should make a fresh peacemaking drive in the Middle East, high ly placed diplomats reported.

headline: ROGERS SEES HOPE FOR VIETNAM TALK
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 15 — Secretary of State William P. Rogers, in an apparent effort to move his position on Viet nam closer to that of the White House, said today that there were “reasonable pros pects” for the peace negotia tions in the long run but that the short‐run prospects were not bright.
author: By Hedrick Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Songmy Defendant Says Nixon Sways Army Court
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, July 15 — A three‐judge Federal court was told today that Sgt. Esequiel Torres, accused a murder in Songmy, South Vietnam, could not receive a fair trial in any American military court be cuase President Nixon had al ready declared him guilty.
author: By Homer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Administration Policy

headline: Members of Presidential Panel Question Witnesses on Campus Unrest
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 15 — There can be no peace on the nation's campuses until there is peace in Vietnam, witness after witness told the President's Commission on Campus Unrest today.
author: By Jack Rosenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Abrams Leaves Hospital
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 15 (AP) — Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, United States com mander in South Vietnam, was released from an Army hospital in Japan today after recovering from a gall bladder operation July 3, his headquarters an nounced. released from an Army hospital in Japan today after recovering from a gall bladder operation July 3, his headquarters an nounced.

headline: Nixon Would Curb Explosives Industry To Abate Bombings
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 15 — The Nixon Administration an nounced today that it would send to Congress next week a bill to regulate the explosives industry in an attempt to keep dynamite and other high ex plosives out of the hands of terrorists.

headline: CONGRESS URGED BY NIXON'S AIDES TO KILL WAR CURB
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 15 — The Nixon Administration strongly urged Congress today to drop the Senate's Cooper Church amendment restrict ing military action in Cambo dia, on the ground that, if en acted, it would infringe on the President's “lawful responsibil ities” as Commander in Chief.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: THIEU DENOUNCES ‘IMMEDIATE PEACE’
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 15—President Nguyen Van Thieu vowed today to “beat to death” those of his countrymen who called for “immediate peace, in surrender to the Communists.”
author: By Takashi Oka Special to The New York Times

headline: 8 Greeks Honored in Athens For Saving Jews From Nazis
lead_paragraph: ATHENS, July 15 — Eight Greeks were honored in Athens today for having helped rescue thousands of Jews from Nazi camps, where 62,000 Greek Jews perished during World War II.

headline: FOE IN CAMBODIA STRIKES IN SOUTH
lead_paragraph: PNOMPEN H. Cambodia, July 15 (Reuters) — A Communist guerrilla force of unknown size was reported today to have struck at Bat Rokar, 28 miles south of Pnompenh, yesterday in an apparent move toward the southern provincial capital of Takeo.

headline: 72 Americans Killed in the War And 729 Wounded Last Week
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 16 (UPI)—Seventy‐two Ameri cans were killed in Indochina last week, raising United States battle deaths for 1970 beyond 3,000, the United States corn mand reported today.

headline: Attack on U.S. Rammed Through Youth Assembly Panel, but It Faces Challenge
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 16 — A denunciation of the United States for its role in Vietnam and what was termed its “rapacious” policy in Latin America was rammed through a World Youth Assembly panel today by a vote of 181 to 73.
author: By Kathleen Teltsch Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam Peace Initiatives

Kissinger over the effect of the Cambodian “incursion” on the prospects for peace in Vietnam less important than need for agreement on a White House policy to get the Paris peace talks moving again.

headline: Rogers, the Constant Negotiator
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 16—Be sides dealing with Russians, Arabs, Israelis and Vietnamese, Secretary of State William P. Rogers is now engaged in periodic negotiations with the White House and, on occasion, even with himself.
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: Agnew T Shirts and Watches Yield $25,000 to 2 Charities
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) — Vice President Agnew's favorite charities received $25, 000 in donations today as royalties from watches and T shirts bearing caricatures of him.

headline: Referendum on War Approved by Senate In Massachusetts
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, July 16 (UPI)—A bill drafting a statewide refer endum question for the Novem ber ballot on future United States military action in Viet nam was passed unanimously tonight by the state Senate and sent to the House.

headline: Letter Charges Torture at Second Vietnamese Prison
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI)—One of the two Repre sentatives who drew attention to the tiger‐cage cells at Con Son Prison in South Vietnam made public today a letter charging that inmates were tortured and subjected to other “inhuman practices” at a sec ond orison in Vietnam.

headline: A South Vietnamese Widow Mourns Her Only Son, Killed in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON. South Vietnam, July 16—Her only son, a 21 ‐ year ‐ old corporal, was killed in Cambodia on May 29 and the loss makes her tremble and cry out. When Mrs. Dro Huan, a widow who works as a porter in the city of Nhatrang, can afford to take the airplane to Sai gon, it is to see his grave, bring him gifts, and talk aloud to him, as thousands of other Vietnamese Buddhist women have done at other graves.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Marines Join a Big Sweep Near Danang
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 18 — (AP) Some 1,500 United States marines have joined 5,000 South Vietnamese soldiers in one of two sweeps southwest of Danang in northern South Vietnam, the United States command announced today.

headline: President vs. Cooper‐Church
lead_paragraph: From the time of the framing of the Constitution it has been the generally accepted view of the American system of checks and balances that “the President proposes, the Congress disposes.” Curiously, for a man who has served in both houses of the legislative branch, President Nixon appears to favor a much narrower interpretation of the role of Congress.

headline: U.N. Youth Assembly Comes to Tumultuous Ending
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 17—The World Youth As sembly came to a noisy and tumultuous ending tonight after approving a message that re flected the political themes that had dominated and fre quently disrupted its nine‐day session.
author: By Kathleen Teltsch Special to The New York Times

headline: Thieu and Lon Nol Confer in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 17 — President Nguyen Van Thieu and Foreign Minister Tran Van Lam of South Viet nam visited Cambodia today and met for nearly two hours with Cambodia's three top leaders.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam Prisoner Torture Described by U. S. Doctor
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 17— An American woman doctor said today that she had treated the victims of beatings and tor ture inflicted in a South Viet namese “interrogation center” that had an American adviser.
author: By Robert M. Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Topics: Vietnam History May Help
lead_paragraph: Our nonvictory in Vietnam will be easier to accept if we can see it in a meaningful his torical context. Without some sense of background, our ac tivities there seem to go on in a vacuum, for no adequate rea sons, and we fill this void of understanding by bringing in slogans and alleging motives from other times and places.
author: By John K. Fairbank

headline: 100 Students in Saigon Battle Police and Liberate 3 Leaders
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17 (Reuters)— About 100 students battled 30 policemen today and recaptured three of their leaders seized during a protest meeting.

headline: ELECTRONIC SENSORS ON MEXICAN BORDER
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 17—The Justice Department is employ ing the electronic sensors developed to detect enemy movements in South Vietnam in its own war against narcotics smuggling and illegal entries on the Mexican border, a de partment spokesman said to night.

headline: Saigon Units in Cambodia Now Playing G.I.'s Role
lead_paragraph: KREK, Cambodia, July 14— A four‐day tour of South Viet namese positions along the bor der in Cambodia reveals strik ing similarities between the South Vietnamese role here and the role of United States forces in South Vietnam during the first years after the 1965 build up.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 Vietnam Amputees Seized With 21 Kilos of Heroin Here
lead_paragraph: Two Army veterans, double amputees who lost their legs while serving in Vietnam IS months ago, were arrested yes terday along with another man and a woman when six detec tives raided a Brooklyn apart ment and seized 21 kilos of heroin having an estimated re tail value of $5‐million.

headline: MRS. BINH ARRIVES FOR VISIT IN INDIA
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI, July 18—Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, foreign minis ter of the Vietcong's provisional revolutionary government, land ed here today amid a raging controversy over her visit.

headline: PRESIDENT WARNS OF ‘PAINFUL’ STEPS IF DEFICIT GROWS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 18 — President Nixon warned Con gress today of “difficult and painful measures” ahead if it persists in running up a budget deficit.

headline: South Vietnamese Students Are Resisting Canadian Efforts to Send Them Home
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL, July 14 — A group of anti‐Saigon students from South Vietnam have band ed together here to resist Cana dian efforts to return them to their war‐torn homeland.
author: By Jay Walz Special to The New York Times

headline: MUSIC FESTIVAL TO AID WAR FOES
lead_paragraph: A 12‐hour festival of rock and folk music will be held at Shea Stadium starting at noon on Aug. 6 to raise funds for senatorial and congressional campaigns of candidates who have been strong opponents of the war in Vietnam and sup porters of a reordering of na tional priorities.
author: By Deirdre Carmody

headline: Tailor Relives Ordeal at Con Son
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 18—A 28‐year‐old village tailor, who can no longer walk or stand up because, he says. he was shackled, beaten and deprived of sufficient food, wa ter, and any exercise or fresh air at Con Son Prison, talked today of his ordeal.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: COALITION TICKET URGED ON VOTERS
lead_paragraph: In an unusual election ploy, New York voters are being urged to support a “coalition ticket” made up of the Con servative candidate for United. States Senator, the Republican candidate for Governor and the Democratic candidate for Con troller.
author: By Clayton Knowles

lead_paragraph: TV Time for President

headline: WAR FOES YIELD ON COFFEEHOUSE
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 18— Antiwar activists have given up their efforts to keep open a controversial coffeehouse at Muldraugh. Ky., in the middle of the Fort Knox military res ervation.

headline: Saigon Seizes Editions Of Five Newspapers
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 18 (UPI)— The South Vietnamese Government con fiscated today's editions of five newspapers, four of them for articles dealing with pris on conditions.

headline: Letters
lead_paragraph: HARDHATTISM, PRO AND CON

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia — The Cambodian Army of 35,000 men had been used mainly to dig ditches and march occasionally in Prince Norodom Sihanouk's pageant—performing both func tions indifferently. Then, four months ago, the armed forces suddenly found themselves faced with the task of defending their country against a battle‐tried in vader.

headline: ALLIES REOCCUPY A BASE NEAR LAOS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 18 — Allied forces established new combat base today at Khamduc, an abandoned United States Special Forces camp 13 miles from the Laotian border in northern South Vietnam.

headline: Frightening Rise in V.D.
lead_paragraph: All of the tragic news today, is not coming from Vietnam, Cambodia or the Middle East. The almost daily reports of the rise in venereal disease to pan demic proportions Is frighten ing. If something isn't done about it, it may well cripple, incapacitate and eventually kill more people than combat.
author: By Howard A. Rusk M.d

headline: Saigon General Accuses Thais Of Shirking on Cambodian Aid
lead_paragraph: BIENHOA, South Vietnam, July 18—A leading South Viet namese general charged today that the leaders of Thailand were shirking their responsibil ity to help defend Cambodia because the United States would not pay them enough money.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: Cambodians Puzzled by Attacks On Former Major Supply Base
lead_paragraph: LONGVEK, Cambodia, July 18—The sprawling Cambodian military supply base here, which once nourished the en tire army but now looks more like an auto graveyard, was attacked by the Vietcong and North Vietnamese last night, the night before, the night be fore that and six other nights since June 24. The commander expects to be hit again tomor row and the day after and the day after that.

headline: Israel Reports Jets Raided Egypt, Jordan and Lebanon
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV, July 19 — Israeli warplanes were reported to have attacked Arab targets on three fronts today, striking the Egyptians in the Suez Canal sector and guerrilla positions in Jordan and Lebanon. All the jets returned safely, the Israeli military spokesman reported.

headline: Enemy Rockets Strike Saigon For the Fourth Time This Year
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, July 20—Enemy forces fired two 100‐pound rockets into the heart of Saigon early today, setting off explosions that reverberated throughout the downtown area.

headline: Antiwar Miss Montana Gave Up Title Gladly
lead_paragraph: HELENA, Mont., July 19 (UPI)—Kathy Huppe, the dark‐haired beauty queen who gave up her Miss Mon tana title rather than keep her antiwar views quiet, said today she was glad her short reign was over.

headline: THIEU DOUBTS END OF WAR WITHIN YEAR
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) —President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam said today that he expected the war in his country to last at least another year but that by the end of 1971 United States troops would oe needed only in supporting roles. He said the supporting role would require more than 50,000 United States soldiers.

headline: ‘Out, Damned Spot!’
lead_paragraph: Like the spot on Lady Macbeth's hand, the stain on the conscience of the United States that was left by the slaughter of civilians in Mylai hamlet, South Viet nam, on March 16, 1968, will not go away.

headline: Calley Wants Charges Dropped or Civilian Trial
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) —Lieutenant William L. Calley Jr., charged with murder in the alleged Mylai massacre in 1968, asked today for a halt in gen eral court‐martial proceedings against him and dismissal of the charges.

headline: MRS. BINH IS READY TO RETURN TO PARIS
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI, July 20 (UPI)— Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, Foreign Minister of the provisional revo lutionary government of South Vietnam, said today that she was willing to return to the Vietnam peace talks in Paris now that President Nixon has named David K. E. Bruce the United States chief negotiator.

headline: 2,900 More Americans Withdrawn From Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 20 (UPI)—A total of 2,900 American servicemen were withdrawn from South Viet nam last week, the United States command said today.

headline: NIXON SUPPORTS THIEU IN OPPOSING FORCED COALITION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 20 — President Nixon today firmly endorsed the opposition of President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam to an im posed coalition government, emphasizing that an election open to all was the best ap proach to a political settlement in Vietnam.
author: By Hedrick Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Little Stir in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 20 — The two rockets that crashed into the center of Saigon early this morning made headlines round the world but barely made themselves felt in the minds of the people of this weary city.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: A Correction
lead_paragraph: Because of a transmission er ror, a Peking dispatch of The Globe and Mail, Toronto, that appeared in The New York Times of July 10 misquoted Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the deposed Chief of State of Cam bodia. The article should have stated that Prince. Sihanouk said a majority of the members of his “government in exile” felt the job of liberating Cam bodia could still be done by Cambodian resistance forces aided by fighters from North Vietnam, rather than “by Cam bodian resistance fighters from North Vietnam,” as it appeared.

headline: A Saigon Captain Sees War Devouring His Life
lead_paragraph: SOMEWHERE IN CAM BODIA—A 32‐year‐old cap tain in the South Vietnamese Army sat outdoors, staring down at his American boots, not up at the moon, while he wondered aloud how much he would mind the loss of an eye, an arm or a leg.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: McGovern Asks Role for Palestinians in Mideast Talks
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 18— Senator George S. McGovern, seeking to meet criticism that he is dovish on the war in Vietnam and hawkish on the Middle East, outlined proposals today for a Middle Eastern settlement, including participa tion of Palestinian refugee or ganizations in Arab ‐ Israeli negotiations.

headline: India Refuses to Arrest Visiting Vietcong Official
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI, July 21—The South Vietnamese representa tive in New Delhi asked the Indian Government today to ar rest Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, the foreign minister of the Vietcong provisional revolutionary gov ernment. The demand was rejected.

headline: Nixon Confers on War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 21 (Reu ters)—President Nixon today held a National Security Council meeting on the Indochina war. The Paris peace talks were be lieved to have been on the agenda. David K.E. Bruce, the President's new chief negotiator at the talks, was present.

headline: AGNEW ATTACKS MEMO AS FRAUD
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 21—An alleged “confidential memo randum” linking Vice President Agnew's office with plans to cancel the 1972 national elec tion and repeal the Bill of Rights was denounced today as a fraud by Mr. Agnew.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam to Alter ‘Tiger Cage’ Cells
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 21—The Government an nounced today that it had sus pended the use of the “tiger cage” cells at the prison on Con Son pending improvements.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: A Prosperous Peace
lead_paragraph: It was argued in this space last week that the heavy cost of the Vietnam war, measured in terms of lost output, diminished profits of business, and reduced real wages labor, tends to refute the old Marxist and New Leftist charge that capitalist economies de pend on war to provide pros perity. author: By Leonard S. Silk

headline: 2 Australian Soldiers Killed By Allied Shells in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: NUIDAT, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 22—(Reuters) —Artillery shells fired by New Zealanders fell around a pla toon of Australian soldiers last night, killing two and wound ing four.

headline: Access to Red Cross Urged
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 21—Rep resentative John E. Moss, chair man of the Foreign Operations subcommittee, urged today that the Red Cross be given full ac cess to all prisons and deten tion centers in Vietnam, North and South.

headline: MRS. BINH RESTATES OFFER ON COALITION

lead_paragraph: Reports that the Vietcong might accept a coalition Gov ernment in South Vietnam had a buoying influence on Ameri can Stock Exchange prices yes terday.

headline: G.I.'s in Vietnam Who Use Marijuana Aided in ‘Amnesty’
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 22 (AP) — The United States Army is trying to get soldiers in Vietnam who use marijuana or other drugs to turn themselves in and get help. It promises that those who do so will not be pun ished.

headline: G.I. Held in Saigon In Effort to Hijack Plane to Hong Kong
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 22—A 20‐year‐old American soldier was taken into custody here this evening after trying to hijack an Air Vietnam pas senger plane Old force it to take him to Hong Kong.

headline: 13 AMERICANS DIE IN VIETNAM CLASH

author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: White House Talk Held By Nixon and Kekkonen
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 23 (Reuters)—President Nixon and President Urho Kekkonen of Finland conferred for 90 minutes today on the outlook for a United States‐Soviet agreement on limiting strate gic armaments and proposals for an East‐West conference on European security.

headline: No Defense Cuts?
lead_paragraph: In a statement that points up one of the most impor tant political issues before the nation, President Nixon has made plain that he intends no significant reduc tions from the present level of defense spending.

headline: U.S. Agrees to Bolster Seoul's Forces
lead_paragraph: HONOLULU, July 23—The United States has agreed to strengthen South Korea's armed forces and defense indus tries before making any sizable reduction in American troop strength in Korea, but it said today that it would proceed with some withdrawals this year.

headline: AMEX PRICES RISE AS VOLUME SLIPS
lead_paragraph: Peace possibilities, both in Vietnam and in the Middle East, apparently fueled a rise on the American Stock Exchange yes terday. The price increases were not broadly dramatic but the index moved up to close at 20.30, up 0.08.

headline: PARIS PEACE TALKS STILL MARKING TIME
lead_paragraph: PARIS, July 23—The Vietnam peace conference went through its 76th plenary session today by marking time. It was consid ered likely to continue doing so at least until the arrival of the new United States delegate, David K. E. Bruce, on Aug. 3

headline: Americans Abandon Base As Foe Presses Build‐up
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23—American airborne troops hastily abandoned a hilltop ar tillery base today just north of the Ashau valley, an enemy stronghold controlling infiltra tion routes from. Laos. The ac tion was taken after heavy bombing strikes and artillery barrages failed to stop a North Vietnamese army build‐up around the post.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: KY SEES SOME GAIN FROM U.S. PULLOUT
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23 (UPI) — Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said today that the removal of American troops from Vietnam would ease his Government's problems by free ing it from political pressures brought about by “stupid” pacifists in the United States.

headline: Laird Predicts Draft Calls Will Fall to 10,000 a Month
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 23—De Tense Secretary Melvin R. Laird said today that draft calls for the rest of 1970 would return to pre‐Vietnam levels of under 10,000 a month.

headline: Aide to U. S. Delegation at U. N. Quits Over Policy Differences
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., JULY 24 — A 29‐year‐old For eign Service officer has re signed his position on the United Stales delegation, say ing that he could no longer support American policies.

headline: U.S. Planes Blast an Abandoned Base Area Near Laos
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 24 (AP)—United States fighter‐bombers today attacked North Vietnamese positions around an abandoned Ameri can artillery base on a moun tain in the far north and struck repeatedly at the sum mit to destroy anything of value left behind.

headline: Red Cross Scored P.O.W.Treatment In Con Son Prison
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 24— Representatives of the Inter national Red Cross have pro tested the treatment of pris oners of war by the South Vietnamese Government. An inspection report shows that they told Saigon that its treat ment of seven of 24 North Vietnamese soldiers at the Con Son Prison violated the Geneva Convention on pris oners of war.
author: By Robert M. Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Airport Project in North Worries Aides in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 16 — Senior American and South Vietnamese planners are concerned over the implications of a very large airfield report ed to be under construction in the southern section of North Vietnam.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: WEST POINTER FAILS IN OBJECTOR APPEAL
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE, July 24 — A Federal judge ruled here today that a West Point graduate who has a “selective conscien tious objection” to the war in Vietnam was not entitled to a discharge from the Army.

headline: The Charm of Mr. Buckley

author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Court Ruling Aids Soldier
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 24 (AP)—A Federal judge has ordered the Army to discharge a Maryland soldier as a con scientious objector as a result of a Supreme Court ruling. Pvt. John D. Aquilino Jr. of Baltimore had sought a dis charge last May, but Federal District Court Judge Adrian Spears had denied the request. headline: ARMY SETS TRIAL ON THEFT IN CLUBS

headline: 2 P.O.W.'s Explain Roles in War

author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Bruce Confers in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 25 (Reuters) — David K. E. Bruce, the new chief American negotiator at the Paris peace talks spent today in consulta tion with officials at the United States Embassy in preparation for taking up his new post, an embassy spokesman said.

headline: 6 BATTLES FOUGHT IN SOUTH VIETNAM AS WAR STEPS UP
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 25—Allied forces reported kill ing 119 North Vietnamese and Vietcong soldiers in stepped‐up fighting in South Vietnam today and yesterday, but a lull was reported on Cambodian battle fields.

headline: Vietnam: Coalition Is the Stumbling Block
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON— In almost every important international ne gotiation, certain words come to be endowed with special magic and special menace. They emerge as symbols of the vital political and military stakes each side is fighting for or against. In the Vietnam talks the “code word,” as President Nixon put it last Monday, is coalition.
author: —Hedrick Smith

headline: Two Men Beaten in Saigon For Raising Vietcong Flag
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 25 — Two young Frenchmen held aloft the Vietcong flag from a war statue in down town Saigon today until it was torn down and they were driven from their perch by crowd that pelted the air with stones and then beat them.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: City Architects and Builders Join in Lobby at Washington Protesting the War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON. July 25—In contrast to recent demonstra tions by construction workers supporting President Nixon's policies in Indochina, a group of New York City area archi tects, engineers and builders who plan the projects the con struction workers build lobbied here this week against those policies.
author: By Richard L. Madden Special to The New York Times

headline: 10 Million Signers Sought On Anneal on War Legality
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) —A new organization has an nounced a campaign to collect 10 million signatures in sup port of Massachusetts' appeal to the Supreme Court to de clare the Vietnam war uncon stitutional.

headline: Sorry, There Is No Perfect Golf Swing
lead_paragraph: MILLIONS of Americans are deeply concerned about infla tion, student riots, Vietnam, the Black Panthers, strikes, bombings, the specter of Abbie Hoffman and the decline of the stock market. author: By David Dempsey

headline: Home Sees Some Gains in Mideast and Indochina
lead_paragraph: LONDON, July 23 (AP)—Sir Alec Douglas‐Home, the British Foreign Secretary, says that both the Egyptians and Israelis are starting to think of nego tiations as their best course. He feels that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization must take account of new Soviet influence south of Europe and must pos sibly consider protection of trade routes around southern Africa.

headline: Saigon Army Desertions Up Nearly 50% in Spring
lead_paragraph: SAIGON. South Vietnam, July 26—Desertions from the South Vietnamese Army in creased drastically in the last few months, averaging nearly 50 per cent higher than the rate last year, according to in formed South Vietnamese sources.
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: Article 1 ‐‐ No Title
author: SPECIAL TO THE NEW YORK TIMES

headline: U.S. STAFF IN SAIGON WARNED OF VIOLENCE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 26 (AP) — The United Stales Embassy has warned its staff against traveling alone in Saigon because of what it called recent acts of violence against Americans by students or other anti‐Government demonstra tors.

headline: Stennis Would Back 2d Cambodia Action
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 26 — Senator John. C. Stennis, chair man of the Senate Armed Serv ices, declared today that he would favor another thrust into Cambodia by United States troops if the Administration found it necessary to clean out enemy sanctuaries there again.

headline: Saigon Force Enters Cambodia In a New Search‐Destroy Drive
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 26—A force of 2,500 South Vietnamese soldiers entered Cambodia today in an operation that initially met only light to moderate opposition.

headline: Candidate's Son Sentenced
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N. H., July 27 (AP) —Eugene Daniell 3d, 23‐year‐ old son of Eugene Daniell, the Mayor of Franklin and a Demo cratic Congressional candidate, received a two‐year prison sen tence today for failing to regis ter for induction into military service. Mayor Daniell, who is running on a platform calling for the withdrawal of United States troops from Vietnam by the end of the year, is seeking his party's nomination for the seat held by Representative James C. Cleveland, a Republi can.

headline: Future Defense Contracts To Be Awarded in Stages
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 27—Secretary of Defense Mel vin R. Laird said today that fu ture defense contracts would be negotiated on a “fly before you buy” basis designed to prevent massive losses to taxpayers be cause of cost overruns.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: New Con Son Study Sought
lead_paragraph: GENEVA, July 27 (UPI)—The International Committee of the Red Cross said today that it would conduct a new inspection of the Con Son prison in South Vietnam as soon as it received permission from the Saigon Government. Committee spokes men said Red Cross delegates in South Vietnam had formally requested such permission.

headline: Opposition in Saigon Fears for Its Political Future
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 27—Antiwar and anti‐Govern ment members of the National Assembly say that harassment over their views is continual, but their most serious fear is for their political survival.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Chou, on French TV, Criticizes the Great Powers
lead_paragraph: PARIS, July 27—Premier Chou En‐lai of Communist China told a French radio and television audience tonight that France and China shared a common opposition to domination and intervention by “the great pow ers” in world affairs.

headline: Strike at Civilian Concern Halts War Pilot Training
lead_paragraph: OZARK, Ala., July 27 (UPI)— Military officials at Fort Rucker said today that they had can celed the contract of a strike plagued civilian concern that had been training military pilots for duty in Vietnam.

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Protected Textiles

headline: Laird Says He Has Power To Order Incursions in Laos
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 27 (Reu ters) — Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird, in testimony before a House subcommittee released today, said that he felt he had authority to permit “short incursions” into Laos.

headline: Vietcong Aide Ends Controversial Visit to India
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI, July 27—Indian officials seemed relieved today that the visit of Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, foreign minister of the Vietcong's provisional revo lutionary government, was over.

headline: Foe Said to Encircle Cambodian Town
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, July 28 (AP)—Heavy fighting was reported yesterday around the former resort town of Kirirom in Cambodia, on plateau 50 miles west of Pnom penh. Four Cambodian battal ions that seized the town 11 days ago were said to be sur rounded by enemy troops and the situation was described as serious.

headline: BOMB JOLTS BANK IN FINANCIAL AREA
lead_paragraph: A pipe bomb exploded early yesterday at the entrance of the Bank of America at 41 Broad Street, shattering glass doors and fracturing marble walls leading into the 10‐story build ing in the heart of Manhattan's financial district.
author: By Lawrence Van Gelder

headline: Hanoi Charges U.S. Raids
lead_paragraph: PARIS, July 28 (Reuters)— North Vietnam charged today that United States B‐52 bomb ers and other aircraft carried out three consecutive days of raids last week on its territory in the northern part of the de militarized zone. Hanoi's dele gation to the Paris peace talks demanded that the American authorities immediately end all acts violating North Vietnam ese sovereignty and security.

headline: BULOVA IS SCORED ON DEFENSE ISSUE
lead_paragraph: The “military industrial com plex” and the antiwar move ment met head‐on yesterday at the annual meeting of the Bulova Watch Company.
author: By William D. Smith

headline: Cambodians, Out of Ammunition, Yield Factory
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 28—Enemy troops occupied the state cement works at Kampot yesterday after the Cambodian defenders ran out of ammu nition and abandoned the fac tory, the Government military spokesman said today.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Arming South Africa

headline: A LAG IN REVENUES PUSHES US. DEFICIT UP TO $2.9‐BILLION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 28—The Government announced today that the Federal budget showed a relatively small deficit of $2.9‐ billion in the fiscal year that ended June 30.
author: By Edwin L. Dale Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Katzenbach, Who Termed Tonkin Resolution ‘Equivalent’ of Declaration of War, Now Backs Its Repeal
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 28 — Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, for mer Under Secretary of State, urged Congress today to repeal the Tonkin Gulf resolution of 1964, which he once described as the “functional equivalent” of a declaration of war in Vietnam.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: 7 Army Officers Face a Further Inquiry on Songmy
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 28 — The Army moved today to hold further investigations of seven officers implicated in the sup pression of information about the alleged mass killing of civil ians two years ago in Songmy, South Vietnam.

headline: At G.I.Post Near DMZ, Nothing Seems to Go Right
lead_paragraph: QUANGTRI COMBAT BASE, South Vietnam, July 28—“We planted $17 worth of flowers out there and What have we got—one damn zinnia!”
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: Marines Held 10 Hours By Vietnamese Crowd
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, July 29 (AP)—A crowd of angry South Vietnamese sur rounded a truck carrying six United States Marines and held it for almost 10 hours until American officials paid nearly $2,500 as compensa tion for a boy killed by the vehicle, reliable sources said today.

headline: MITCHELL DECRIES RUMOR ON '72 VOTE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 29 — The Justice Department is in vestigating to determine who originated the rumor that the Nixon Administration was con templating canceling the 1972 elections and repealing the Bill of Rights.
author: By Warren Weaver Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Songmy Suspect Cleared
lead_paragraph: BROWNSVILLE, Tex., July 29 (UPI)—Sgt. Esiquiel Torres, charged in connection with the Songrny massacre, was found not guilty today of firing a rifle near a Brownsville tavern July 19. The jury deliberated 1 hour 15 minutes following day long testimony.

headline: In The Nation: The Great Vietnam Turnabout
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 29—One of the most important facts of American political life, just eighteen months after the Nixon Administration took of fice, is that it is now the de fender of the war in Vietnam while the Democratic party has all but officially swung into op position to it.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: RED CROSS LIMITED IN VISIT TO CON SON
lead_paragraph: GENEVA, July 29 — The In ternational Committee of the Red Cross said today that its representatives who visited the Con Son prison in South Viet nam failed to learn of the ex istence of the so‐called tiger cages.

headline: POPE IS PREPARING MESSAGE ON DRUGS
lead_paragraph: ROME, July 29 — Pope Paul VI is planning to issue a spe cial message to youth on the dangers of drug abuse, a sub ject on which President Nix on's special envoy to the Vati can, Henry Cabot Lodge, held long and detailed talks during his first official visit to Rome.
author: By Alfred Friendly Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnam Peace Plan
lead_paragraph: President Nixon's news conference today, President Thieu's radio‐television address tomorrow and Ambas sador Bruce's projected arrival in Paris Monday could open a new phase in the efforts to negotiate a political settlement of the Vietnam war. Mr. Thieu will clarify his proposals on a cease‐fire in Vietnam, which pre sumably could be laid on the table in Paris next Thursday.

headline: Saigon Gets Landing Craft
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, July 29 (AP)—The United States Navy: turned over five landing craft and a small drydock to the South Vietnamese Navy to day at a ceremony in Danang. The Navy announced that 2,000 of its men had left. Vietnam during July under President Nixon's troop‐withdrawal pro gram. By last Thursday Ameri can Navy strength in Vietnam totaled 24,300 men, but this does not include ships of the Seventh Fleet operating off the coast.

headline: Cambodian Force Driven From Kirirom
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 29 — Vietnamese Communist forces have driven Cambodian Government troops from Kiri rom, the hilltop resort that has been the scene of fighting for three weeks.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
lead_paragraph: Ladies and gentlemen, we've had a slight delay because the audio in the room—I hope that all of you will ask your questions quite loudly.

headline: Habib, Leaving Post in Paris, Bids Hanoi Avoid Propaganda
lead_paragraph: PARIS, July 30 — Philip C. Habib ended his tenure as the ranking American at the Viet nam peace talks by telling the enemy today the negotiations “can be successful” if not mis used for propaganda.
author: By Eric Pace Special to The New York Times

headline: NIXON REASSURES ISRAELIS U.S. PLAN POSES NO DANGER
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 30 — President Nixon tonight sought to assure Israel that she can accept the United States pro posal for a limited cease‐fire in the Middle East “without fear that by entering negotia tions her position may be com promised or jeopardized in that period.”.
author: By Hedrick Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: 71 Senators Back a Firm Mideast Policy
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 30—A group of 71 Senators today pub licly endorsed a firm Adminis tration position on the Middle East, asserting that the Soviet Union should be warned of the dangers of provoking the Unit ed States.

headline: Thieu Sees a Need For 50,000 Troops From U.S. After 73
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 30 — President Nguyen Van Thieu said tonight that “residual force” of about 50, 000 American troops would be required in South Vietnam after 1973 to “guarantee the peace.”
author: By James P. Sterba Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor of The Times
lead_paragraph: Proposal for Vietnam

headline: SENATE GROUP URGES ACTION ON P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI)—A group of Senators made an effort today to stir national indignation over treat ment of United States prisoners of war, whom they termed the “forgotten men”, of the Viet nam war.

headline: U.S. COURT URGED TO FREE CHICAGO 8
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, July 30 — The United States. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit was asked today to reverse the con victions of all defendents in the Chicago conspiracy trial be cause of recently disclosed elec tronic surveillance of Bobby G. Seale.
author: By J. Anthony Lukas Special to The New York Times

headline: U. S. War Deaths 77 in Week, Up From 66
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 31 (AP) — The United States command an nounced yesterday that 77 Americans were killed in action in South Vietnam in the week ended Saturday, 11 more than the week before. However, it said the number of American combat dead in the last four weeks, 276, was the lowest in four years.
